segments.key_quote: A travelling mendicant can meet the needs of the body, namely thirst and hunger, by the gifts of nature without being a beggar at the doors of the householder.
segments.summary: The speaker explains Narada Muni's travels and how a mendicant should rely on nature's gifts rather than begging, emphasizing self-sufficiency and detachment.
segments.transcript: In this session we will be discussing from the 14th verse of the 6th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. Parishranta Indriya Atma Aham Trd Parito Bubhukshitaha Snatva Peetva Hrade Nadya Upas Prishto Gata Shramaha. The meaning of this verse is: Thus travelling, I felt tired, both bodily and mentally, and I was both thirsty and hungry. So I took a bath in a river, lake, and also drank water. By contacting water, I got relief from my exhaustion. So Narav Muni is describing his experiences while travelling to that place. In that holy place, on the way he came across so many different kinds of prosperous towns, gold mines, beautiful lakes filled with lotus flowers and singing birds, but he was not attracted by any of those. His mind was fixed on reaching that sacred spot where he could sit. So what about the demands of the body while travelling? A travelling mendicant can meet the needs of the body, namely thirst and hunger, by the gifts of nature without being a beggar at the doors of the householder.

segments.key_quote: So to awaken them to spiritual reality is the duty of a traveling transcendentalist Parivrajakacharya.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the role of a traveling transcendentalist in enlightening householders who are often engrossed in family affairs.
segments.transcript: By Krishna's arrangement, he could get the needs of the body. By Krishna's arrangement, there is sufficient food and water available for any person who just wants to dedicate himself for spiritual life without any need for begging at the door of a householder. So Srila Prabhupada further says the mendicant therefore does not go to the house of a householder to beg but to enlighten him spiritually. There is no need for begging, but then on the plea of begging sometimes is transcendent. A spiritualist may go and approach a householder simply to take the opportunity to enlighten the householder spiritually. That is a real purpose because people, especially in household life, they become busy with their work, family maintenance, providing for the needs of the family members, etc. Many responsibilities as regards the maintenance of the family. So they get more or less lost in such family affairs. So to awaken them to spiritual reality is the duty of a traveling transcendentalist.

segments.key_quote: Any man who is not materially prosperous can take shelter of these great mountains and he will be provided with everything required.
segments.summary: The speaker describes the Himalayas as a place of abundance, providing both material and spiritual necessities for those seeking shelter.
segments.transcript: Parivrajakacharya. Now Srila Prabhupada especially mentions elsewhere about the Himalaya mountains. He says that the Himalaya mountains are famous for all richnesses. What are the riches in the Himalaya mountains? There are innumerable caves to live in, numberless trees of good fruits to eat, good springs to drink water from, and profuse drugs and minerals to cure diseases. Any man who is not materially prosperous can take shelter of these great mountains and he will be provided with everything required. Both the materialist and the spiritualist can take advantage of the great shelter of the Himalayas. So Naran Muni is heading to the Himalayas only and in that place everything is provided for by the superior arrangement of the Supreme Lord.

segments.key_quote: There are springs even hot water springs so that one can take bath when it is very cold in the hot water of the hot water spring and there are so many herbs to cure diseases.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the resources available in the Himalayas, including fruits, flowers, caves, and hot springs, emphasizing its suitability for secluded meditation.

There are springs, even hot water springs so that one can take bath when it is very cold in the hot water of the hot water spring and there are so many herbs to cure diseases. In case somebody becomes diseased then there are so many herbs to cure the diseases so everything is provided for both materially and spiritually and they can sit in a secluded place and nicely do meditation without being disturbed or bothered by anyone else so the fifteenth words Narada Muni further describes his travel.

segments.summary: The speaker introduces the next verse and explains Narada Muni's meditation on the Supersoul in a secluded forest, emphasizing the use of intelligence learned from liberated souls.
